On 6/9/05, Gordon Mohr (@Internet Archive) <gojomo@...> wrote:
> Is=
 the crash a SIGSEGV?

Yup, everytime.

> We've seen those on our spanking-=
new dual-opteron systems
> intermittently. Our current theory is that it's =
a JVM GC
> issue; at least one crash output log showed a "GCTaskThread"
> a=
s the culprit.

In fact, my latest run showed that exact thing.  Would you =
be
interested in a bunch of logs from those crashes?
 
> Using the "-XX:+Us=
eSerialGC" to force the use of the classic
> garbage collector (which is st=
ill the default on uniprocessor
> and <2GB RAM machines) has, so far, clear=
ed our crashes up.

Thanks!  I'll try it and report back.  That would be gr=
eat if its all
I needed to do!
 
> One other gotcha I *think* I've seen wit=
h the Sun 1.5.0_03
> 64bit JVM: using the nifty new 'jmap' and 'jstack' uti=
lities
> seems to be correlated with JVM lockups, where threads
> wind up w=
aiting for wake signals that never arrive. In some
> such lockups, even a '=
kill -9' won't exit the JVM -- only
> connecting to the process with 'gdb' =
and issuing its internal
> 'kill' command works.

I haven't had any thread =
lockup issues, but I'll report back if I see
that behavior.  Actually, I gu=
ess there's always a chance that a
ToeThread is locked up and I wouldn't no=
tice (or is there?).

> Hope this helps,

Thank you very much.

> Matt Itti=
gson wrote:
> > I'm having a problem (this time I'm sure its actually with =
Heritrix)
> > with hard crashes.  I have the hs_err_pidXXX.logs and the
> >=
 heritrix_out.log, but neither points me clearly toward the problem.
> > I'=
m running Heritrix-200505310807 (though I've had crashes with
> > previous =
versions, including 1.4, as well) on a dual Opteron, with 2G
> > of ram, ru=
nning Linux 2.6.9, glibc 2.3.4, JVM 1.5.0_03.
> >
> > Is there some logging=
 I could turn on (or perhaps somewhere I could
> > look) which could point =
me toward the right direction?  I'm guessing
> > it has to do with a certai=
n URL getting hit, which causes the crash,
> > so if I could narrow down wh=
at exactly Heritrix is up to right before,
> > maybe I could figure out how=
 to skip the particular URL's.
> >
> > A little more information:  In the p=
ast, the crashes have mostly been
> > consistent.  My previous usage model =
was to break large seed files
> > into smaller chunks, and Heritrix would u=
sually crash consistently on
> > the chunks with problems.  Sometimes, re-r=
unning a seed chunk which
> > would cause a crash could run to competion wi=
thout crashing (becase I
> > retire host-based queues at 200 URL's, this co=
uld be due to the bad
> > URL being occasionally skipped for being out of s=
cope), but most of
> > the time the crash would be consistent.  I'm now con=
tinually loading
> > seeds via cmdline-jmx.  I've changed my program to out=
put exactly at
> > what point the crash happens (when the connection is ref=
used), but
> > that won't really make clear exactly which URL's are being c=
rawled at
> > the time.
> >
> > Are there known bugs that would cause hard =
crashes I could look into?
> > Would posting the log files to this list hel=
p debug the problem?  Is
> > there logging I could turn on to show exactly =
what was being crawled
> > at the time of the crash?  Any other ideas of ap=
proaches to take
> > toward solving the problem?
> >
> > Thanks.
